Literature Review: The zebrafish has emerged as a mainstream model for in vivo systems pharmacology and toxicology, offering a scalable and cost-effective alternative to traditional mammalian models. This review aims to provide an overview of the current state of the field, highlighting the advantages and limitations of using zebrafish as a model organism for studying chemical biological interactions. We will discuss the progress made in integrating information content across preclinical model organisms and the incorporation of rigorous analytics, including closed-loop deep learning, to create systems pharmacology and toxicology models. The literature review will also examine the current applications of zebrafish in systems pharmacology and toxicology, including its use in predicting drug efficacy and toxicity, identifying potential drug targets, and understanding disease mechanisms.The zebrafish has several advantages over traditional mammalian models, including its rapid breeding cycle, genetic tractability, and transparent embryos. These characteristics make it an ideal model for high-throughput screening and automated phenotyping. The zebrafish genome has also been fully sequenced, allowing for the development of targeted gene editing tools such as CRISPR/Cas9. This has enabled researchers to study the genetic basis of disease and develop novel therapeutic strategies.One of the key challenges in using zebrafish as a model organism is the need to translate findings from the laboratory to the clinic. This requires the development of robust and reliable methods for predicting drug efficacy and toxicity in humans. Recent advances in machine learning and deep learning have shown promise in this area, with studies demonstrating the ability to predict drug efficacy and toxicity using zebrafish data.In addition to its use in predicting drug efficacy and toxicity, the zebrafish has also been used to identify potential drug targets and understand disease mechanisms. Studies have shown that zebrafish can be used to model a range of human diseases, including cancer, cardiovascular disease, and neurological disorders. The zebrafish has also been used to study the effects of environmental toxins and pollutants, providing valuable insights into the impact of these substances on human health.The integration of information content across preclinical model organisms is also an important area of research in systems pharmacology and toxicology. This involves the development of databases and tools that can integrate data from multiple model organisms, allowing researchers to identify common patterns and trends across species. Recent advances in machine learning and deep learning have shown promise in this area, with studies demonstrating the ability to integrate data from multiple model organisms using closed-loop deep learning.In conclusion, the zebrafish has emerged as a mainstream model for in vivo systems pharmacology and toxicology, offering a scalable and cost-effective alternative to traditional mammalian models. The literature review has highlighted the advantages and limitations of using zebrafish as a model organism, including its rapid breeding cycle, genetic tractability, and transparent embryos. The use of zebrafish in predicting drug efficacy and toxicity, identifying potential drug targets, and understanding disease mechanisms has also been demonstrated. The integration of information content across preclinical model organisms is also an important area of research, with recent advances in machine learning and deep learning showing promise in this area.
